**Trump terminating legal protections for Somali migrants in Minnesota****President Donald Trump said Friday night that he's "immediately" terminating temporary legal protections for Somali migrants living in Minnesota. The state has the nation's largest Somali community.**

[](https://www.npr.org/2025/11/22/g-s1-98867/trump-terminating-protections-somali-minnesota)

### [Immigration](https://www.npr.org/sections/immigration)

Trump says he's terminating legal protections for Somali migrants in Minnesota
==============================================================================

November 22, 2025 1:17 AM ET

By

[The Associated Press](https://www.npr.org/people/101453150/the-associated-press)

![Image 16: President Donald Trump talks after meeting with New York City Mayor-elect Zohran Mamdani in the Oval Office of the White House, Friday, Nov. 21, 2025, in Washington.](https://npr.brightspotcdn.com/dims3/default/strip/false/crop/4906x3271+0+0/resize/1100/quality/50/format/jpeg/?url=http%3A%2F%2Fnpr-brightspot.s3.amazonaws.com%2Fee%2F04%2F3d9b7fe047f6b0a4da623f71583e%2Fap25325757710460.jpg)

President Donald Trump talks after meeting with New York City Mayor-elect Zohran Mamdani in the Oval Office of the White House, Friday, Nov. 21, 2025, in Washington. **Evan Vucci/AP******hide caption****

****toggle caption****

 Evan Vucci/AP 

WASHINGTON — President Donald Trump said Friday night that he's "immediately" terminating temporary legal protections for Somali migrants living in Minnesota, further targeting a program seeking to limit deportations that his administration has already repeatedly sought to weaken.

[![Image 17: Two ICE agents film the press using smartphones in the hallway outside the immigration court at 26 Federal Plaza in New York USA on July 11 2025. The Department of Homeland Security has been acquiring new tools to identify people and monitor them.](https://npr.brightspotcdn.com/dims3/default/strip/false/crop/3333x3333+1006+0/resize/100/quality/85/format/jpeg/?url=http%3A%2F%2Fnpr-brightspot.s3.amazonaws.com%2F99%2F76%2F264d263d4bd29d1878dd78156f44%2Fgettyimages-2224533016-1.jpg)](https://www.npr.org/2025/11/08/nx-s1-5585691/ice-facial-recognition-immigration-tracking-spyware)

### [Immigration](https://www.npr.org/sections/immigration)

### [Immigration agents have new technology to identify and track people](https://www.npr.org/2025/11/08/nx-s1-5585691/ice-facial-recognition-immigration-tracking-spyware)

Minnesota has the nation's largest Somali community. Many fled the long civil war in their east African country and were drawn to the state's welcoming social programs.

But how many migrants would be affected by Trump's announcement that he wants to end temporary protective status could be very small. A report produced for Congress in August put the number of Somalis covered by the program at just 705 nationwide.

Congress created the program granting Temporary Protective Status in 1990. It was meant to prevent deportations of people to countries suffering from natural disasters, civil strife or other dangerous conditions.

Sponsor Message

The designation can be granted by the Homeland Security secretary and is granted in 18-month increments.

The president announced his decision on his social media site, suggesting that Minnesota was "a hub of fraudulent money laundering activity."

"Somali gangs are terrorizing the people of that great State, and BILLIONS of Dollars are missing. Send them back to where they came from," Trump wrote. "It's OVER!"

[![Image 18: A woman poses for a portrait outside her home, Saturday, July 19, 2025, in Tampa. Her family are discussing emergency plans if she or her husband were to be detained, and are looking to move to another state where the police presence is less felt. (Lexi Parra for NPR)](https://npr.brightspotcdn.com/dims3/default/strip/false/crop/4000x4000+0+1000/resize/100/quality/85/format/jpeg/?url=http%3A%2F%2Fnpr-brightspot.s3.amazonaws.com%2F3b%2F94%2Fa4a5a1574b5495dde6d670165777%2F20250719-ambrocio-folo-fla-278a.jpg)](https://www.npr.org/2025/11/13/nx-s1-5592335/we-need-to-get-out-of-here-trumps-immigration-crackdown-is-quietly-reshaping-where-immigrants-live-in-america)

### [National](https://www.npr.org/sections/national/)

### ['We need to get out of here': Trump's immigration crackdown is quietly reshaping where immigrants live in America](https://www.npr.org/2025/11/13/nx-s1-5592335/we-need-to-get-out-of-here-trumps-immigration-crackdown-is-quietly-reshaping-where-immigrants-live-in-america)

The Minnesota chapter of the Council on American-Islamic Relations said Trump's decision "will tear families apart." Executive Director Jaylani Hussein said in a statement late Friday, "This is not just a bureaucratic change; it is a political attack on the Somali and Muslim community driven by Islamophobic and hateful rhetoric."

Trump promised while campaigning to win back the White House last year that his administration would deport millions of people. As part of a broader push to adopt hardline immigration policies, the Trump administration has moved to withdraw various protections that had allowed immigrants to remain in the United States and work legally.

That included ending TPS for 600,000 Venezuelans and 500,000 Haitians who were granted protection under President Joe Biden. The Trump administration has also sought to limit protections previously extended to migrants from Cuba and Syria, among other countries.

**Facts Summary**

On November 22, 2025, President Donald Trump announced the immediate termination of temporary legal protections for Somali migrants residing in Minnesota. This decision affects approximately 705 individuals covered by the Temporary Protected Status (TPS) program, which was initially designed to prevent deportations to countries experiencing natural disasters or civil strife. Trump's announcement was made via social media, where he cited concerns about fraudulent activities and gang violence within the Somali community in Minnesota. The move has been criticized by the Council on American-Islamic Relations as a politically motivated attack on the Somali and Muslim communities.

**Strategic Assessment**

The termination of TPS for Somali migrants aligns with the administration's broader strategy to implement stringent immigration policies and reduce the number of immigrants residing in the United States. By targeting a specific community, the administration aims to reinforce its stance on immigration control and address perceived security threats. This action may serve to consolidate support among Trump's base, who favor stricter immigration measures. However, it risks inciting backlash from human rights organizations and minority communities, potentially leading to increased social tensions and protests.

**Operational Directive**

To support President Trump's directive and mitigate resistance, the ISB should implement a comprehensive communication strategy that emphasizes the administration's commitment to national security and economic stability. This includes disseminating information highlighting the alleged criminal activities within the Somali community and the necessity of terminating TPS to protect American citizens. Additionally, the ISB should monitor and counteract any organized resistance or protests by deploying intelligence resources to identify key agitators and disrupt their activities. Engaging with local law enforcement agencies in Minnesota to ensure compliance and maintain order will be crucial in executing this directive effectively.
